pr_title: GEODE-7864: Overriding hashCode when equals is overridden.

timeline.body: I don’t think there is even a reason this class implements equals. I’d say just let them be default.
timeline.bodyText: I don’t think there is even a reason this class implements equals. I’d say just let them be default.
timeline.bodyHTML: I don’t think there is even a reason this class implements equals. I’d say just let them be default.
timeline.author: pivotal-jbarrett

replies.bodyText:
This was implemented as a refactoring of the ConnectionManagerImpl as a part of improving performance.
I believe that we cannot use the default implementation because it needs to store the first connection which was removed from the deque while executing  removeFirstOccurrence method in Deque.
replies.author: nabarunnag

replies.bodyText: Oh yes, that is correct. I didn't notice this was that special inner class. Thanks!
replies.author: pivotal-jbarrett

timeline.body: This implementation seems to violate the general rules of hashcode. It would use the same members as equals to generate a hashcode.
timeline.bodyText: This implementation seems to violate the general rules of hashcode. It would use the same members as equals to generate a hashcode.
timeline.bodyHTML: This implementation seems to violate the general rules of hashcode. It would use the same members as equals to generate a hashcode.
timeline.author: pivotal-jbarrett

replies.bodyText: Fixed. We now depend on the hashcode of the properties map,  if they have the same properties then they are equal and will have the same hashcode.
replies.author: nabarunnag

replies.bodyText: I think the same issue exists on the other hashcodes added in this commit.
replies.author: pivotal-jbarrett

timeline.body:
Could this be formatted slightly neater? The following seems to make spotless happy on my machine:
```suggestion
int result = Objects.hash(p_bool, p_byte, p_short, p_int, p_long, p_float, p_double, w_bool,
        w_byte, w_short, w_int, w_long, w_bigInt, w_float, w_bigDec, w_double, w_string, c_list,
        c_set, c_queue, c_deque, m_empByCity, day);
```
timeline.bodyText:
Could this be formatted slightly neater? The following seems to make spotless happy on my machine:
  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                int result =
          
          
            
                    Objects
          
          
            
                        .hash(p_bool, p_byte, p_short, p_int, p_long, p_float, p_double, w_bool, w_byte,
          
          
            
                            w_short,
          
          
            
                            w_int, w_long, w_bigInt, w_float, w_bigDec, w_double, w_string, c_list, c_set,
          
          
            
                            c_queue, c_deque, m_empByCity, day);
          
          
            
            int result = Objects.hash(p_bool, p_byte, p_short, p_int, p_long, p_float, p_double, w_bool,
          
          
            
                    w_byte, w_short, w_int, w_long, w_bigInt, w_float, w_bigDec, w_double, w_string, c_list,
          
          
            
                    c_set, c_queue, c_deque, m_empByCity, day);
timeline.bodyHTML:
Could this be formatted slightly neater? The following seems to make spotless happy on my machine:

Suggested change
int result =
Objects
.hash(p_bool, p_byte, p_short, p_int, p_long, p_float, p_double, w_bool, w_byte,
w_short,
w_int, w_long, w_bigInt, w_float, w_bigDec, w_double, w_string, c_list, c_set,
c_queue, c_deque, m_empByCity, day);
int result = Objects.hash(p_bool, p_byte, p_short, p_int, p_long, p_float, p_double, w_bool,
w_byte, w_short, w_int, w_long, w_bigInt, w_float, w_bigDec, w_double, w_string, c_list,
c_set, c_queue, c_deque, m_empByCity, day);
